gospel.text:
[[Lc 8,4]]When a large crowd gathered, with people from one town after another journeying to Jesus, he spoke in a parable.
[[Lc 8,5]]A sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some seed fell on the path and was trampled, and the birds of the sky ate it up.
[[Lc 8,6]]Some seed fell on rocky ground, and when it grew, it withered for lack of moisture.
[[Lc 8,7]]Some seed fell among thorns, and the thorns grew with it and choked it.
[[Lc 8,8]]And some seed fell on good soil, and when it grew, it produced fruit a hundredfold." After saying this, he called out, "Whoever has ears to hear ought to hear."
[[Lc 8,9]]Then his disciples asked him what the meaning of this parable might be.
[[Lc 8,10]]He answered, "Knowledge of the mysteries of the kingdom of God has been granted to you; but to the rest, they are made known through parables so that 'they may look but not see, and hear but not understand.'
[[Lc 8,11]]This is the meaning of the parable. The seed is the word of God.
[[Lc 8,12]]Those on the path are the ones who have heard, but the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts that they may not believe and be saved.
[[Lc 8,13]]Those on rocky ground are the ones who, when they hear, receive the word with joy, but they have no root; they believe only for a time and fall away in time of trial.
[[Lc 8,14]]As for the seed that fell among thorns, they are the ones who have heard, but as they go along, they are choked by the anxieties and riches and pleasures of life, and they fail to produce mature fruit.
[[Lc 8,15]]But as for the seed that fell on rich soil, they are the ones who, when they have heard the word, embrace it with a generous and good heart, and bear fruit through perseverance."
gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Luke

first_reading.text:
[[1_Co 15,35]]Brothers and sisters : Someone may say, "How are the dead raised? With what kind of body will they come back?"
[[1_Co 15,36]]You fool! What you sow is not brought to life unless it dies.
[[1_Co 15,37]]And what you sow is not the body that is to be but a bare kernel of wheat, perhaps, or of some other kind;
[[1_Co 15,42]]So also is the resurrection of the dead. It is sown corruptible; it is raised incorruptible.
[[1_Co 15,43]]It is sown dishonorable; it is raised glorious. It is sown weak; it is raised powerful.
[[1_Co 15,44]]It is sown a natural body; it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual one.
[[1_Co 15,45]]So, too, it is written, "The first man, Adam, became a living being," the last Adam a life-giving spirit.
[[1_Co 15,46]]But the spiritual was not first; rather the natural and then the spiritual.
[[1_Co 15,47]]The first man was from the earth, earthly; the second man, from heaven.
[[1_Co 15,48]]As was the earthly one, so also are the earthly, and as is the heavenly one, so also are the heavenly.
[[1_Co 15,49]]Just as we have borne the image of the earthly one, we shall also bear the image of the heavenly one.
